body.p:
I wrote you a few days
since, (or rather to Mrs Cozens) mentioning the
supposed suicide of Mr E. L. Andrews. of this city.

Thinking you might wish to know more
on the subject, I will give you all the particulars
I know of it.—

The house of E L Andrews & Co. (Mobile) bought
largely of Cotton last year and in consequence must
have met with very heavy losses. This year again
they bought largely, and with every prospect of
realizing a splendid fortune—So sanguine were
they of success, that E. L. A. said publicly on one occasion
that he would not ship another Bale, as he had
shipped enough to satisfy his utmost wishes of
fortune—This was on the receipt of news from
Europe announcing a rise of half penny, and occurred
about two months back—All these hopes were destroyed
by the monied presence in Europe & the consequent decline
of cotton and the Farm? became involved seriously
but had not met with a protest.___On Friday
last, Mr A. expected to receive a large sum of money
by an up river boat, to meet the payments of
Saturday—the money did not come—he left the
office at dinner time and went home, gave his wife
One thousand Dolls. (so report says) returned to his office
and told his partner that there was no hope for things

His partner said they could meet the next days
demand by borrowing—Mr. A. remarked that they
could not as honorable men borrow when they were
not certain of replacing the money.—Neither his
partner nor family suspected his intention at this time
He did not go home in the evening, but was seen
an spoken to by several persons—The next morning
his Hat & Umbrella was found on the wharf—
A letter written to his partner on Thursday gave
full instructions about the conduct of the business
a postscript of Friday night told where his hat
and umbrella would be found, indicating the manner
and place of his death. Two other letters written
on Friday evening—one to his wife and one to
a friend requesting his attention to his wifes welfare
and stating that he was determined not to live
to see his name dishonored= This was all
that was known at the time I wrote on Sunday
search for his body proved of no avail, and
Telegraphic dispatches brought the news that
Mr. Z. Andrews of N. Orleans was also missing and
supposed to have committed Suicide___The knowledge
that the English Steamer left Mobile Point late
saturday morning, threw a suspicious air over
the whole combine with the absence of the two
brothers and the fruitless search for the dead
body__This morning, Mr E L. A.s body was found
on the same spot he had indicated in his letter.
He had taken the leaden paper holders from

his office and placed them in his pantaloons
pockets, also some pieces of Iron and then jumped
overboard__His watch, purse &c. were found
in his office__This is all, and now many
that were saying that the d_d Jew had run away
are shuddering at the cool desperation of his death.

Coupled with the absence of Mr. A of N. Orleans
it is singular. They were in the habit of corresponding
daily=E L. A. wrote to Z on saturday—that night he
committed suicide—Z. A. recd the letter at 10 am. Sunday
and has not been heard of since ____ Some years
ago, when Sol. Andrews failed it was well known that
his two brothers visited him in prison at N. O. and
brought him poison and end? to persuade
him to make use of it. The repeatedly said
they would never Survive a Protest. E L. A.
succeeded Sol. in business here. I believe eleven
years ago, and despite the dishonor and opprob?
on the name made his house one of the first here
and maintained it so. He was noted for his
high toned business character, and I am glad to
say that those who knew the man, rejected all
thought of his running away.__He has proved
the truth of their opinion and though I cannot
approve the act I thanked heaven when I saw
the body drawn from the water this morning
that it was so, and that the Jew, acknowledged
a higher sense of honor, though false, than many
of the cringing, fashionable scoundrels, who

are breaking daily around me without other
thought then to save all they can for themselves.
I have written you a long letter on what I
fear is a disagreeable matter to you as I know
you love not such subjects, and I can urge
no other excuse save that I felt deeply interested
from his being a jew and prejudices being strong
against the race in this place__I have been
nervous & excited ever since hearing of his absence
and it is the reaction of this state that has
led me I suppose to write you what I have.
Mr. A. has through life taught the people here
that a jew may retain a rank among the first
in social life & business standing—his death has
thrown a gloom over all who associated with
him and over the whole community=

I have spun this letter out long enough
and must bring it to a close, I would be
glad if you would drop me a line or two
occasionally—Perhaps you might give me
some idea of what prospect I have of getting
business from our people when I return__
By the Bye. Please to order for me a book, entitled,
Traité Thèorique et Pratique des Maladies des
Jeux = by. Professor L. A. Desmarres (Paris 1847)
If Mr. Hart has not got it—get Pennington to
import it for me. It will be in Philaa. nearly
as soon as I get there, I shall want it then.—

M & I. are enjoying excellent health, the warm
weather affects me somewhat, but I hope
to get off in the course of five weeks so
that I have no fear on that score.—

Remember both of us to “Our Dear Mother
and believe us sincere in the (E. P. L.) expressions”
of esteem & affection we tender yourself.
Hoping to hear as usual from you

I have not seen Col. Solomons
saw his brother and delivered your message
said he would attend to it.
SW.

I understand Col Solomons is to escort Mrs. E. Lill
to her friends in N York so you will no doubt see him
shortly Mrs. A. was a N. Yorker, name. Jessica Jude_ (Judah?)

I send newspaper slips, at the risk of making you pay
two Dimes for your letter, that you may see the
standing of Mr. a. in this community—He was buried
as a Jew.—
